sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying rod
message_1: A physics experiment involves a copper rod with a length of 15 cm and a diameter of 2.5 mm, carrying a current of 5 A. What is the magnitude and direction of the magnetic field, at a distance of 3 cm from the center of the rod, assuming it is infinitely long? Use the right-hand rule to determine the direction of the magnetic field.
message_2:
To find the magnetic field at a distance of 3 cm from the center of the rod, we can use Ampere's Law, which states that the magnetic field (B) around a current-carrying wire is given by:

B = (μ₀ * I) / (2 * π * r)

where μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10⁻⁷ Tm/A), I is the current in the wire (5 A), and r is the distance from the center of the rod (3 cm = 0.03 m).

B = (4π × 10⁻⁷ Tm/A * 5 A) / (2 * π * 0.03 m)

B ≈ (20π × 10⁻⁷ Tm/A) / (0.06 m)

B ≈ 1.67 × 10⁻⁵ T

So, the magnitude of the magnetic field at a distance of 3 cm from the center of the rod is approximately 1.67 × 10⁻⁵ T.

To determine the direction of the magnetic field, we can use the right-hand rule. If you point your right thumb in the direction of the current (which is along the rod), your fingers will curl around the rod in the direction of the magnetic field. In this case, the magnetic field will form concentric circles around the rod, with the direction depending on the orientation of the rod and the direction of the current.
